newsitem.title: GERMANY: German exhibition shows danger of neo-Nazi threat.
newsitem.headline: German exhibition shows danger of neo-Nazi threat.

text.p: The vast majority of Germans arrested for neo-Nazi violence are under 20 years old, a federal watchdog agency said on Wednesday when it opened a new exhibition warning youths to keep away from the far right.

The Federal Office for the Protection of the Constitution (BfV) said 78 percent of arrested neo-Nazis were in their teens and most of the broader far-right violence that has plagued Germany since its 1990 unification was caused by those under 21.

"Extremist right-wing arguments are easily spread among young people seeking direction," said Gerhard Boekel, environment minister for the state of Hesse, in opening the exhibition called "Democracy is Vulnerable".

"Developing political awareness is one of the best ways of combating the problem," he added in a speech opening the exhibition at the Hesse Ministry for Science and Art in this western German city. The exhibition runs through September 26.
BfV President Peter Frisch said that as a child he had experienced the old form of national socialism.
"Directly because of that it is important that we make every effort to deny right-wing extremism in Germany any chance of success," he said.
The BfV said there are around 6,000 violent right-wing extremists operating in Germany. Around 2,500 of these were neo-Nazis.

The most striking display at the exhibition was of weapons seized from neo-Nazi groups over the last few years. They included a machinegun, pistols, bayonets, martial arts weapons, baseball bats and switchblades.

The agency warned that in attempting to raise awareness for their own cause, right-wing extremists have been quick to use new technology. The exhibition shows how neo-Nazis have their own internet sites offering contacts to far-right groups.
Alexander Puest, an 18-year-old student from Wiesbaden, said: "It's very interesting. They could maybe have showed more of the victims to show the results of these actions."
The exhibition also includes a map which shows the number of attacks and the number of fatalities in the individual states between 1991 and 1995.

The greatest number of attacks were in the western state of North Rhine-Westphalia, with 2,153, followed by Lower Saxony, also in the west with 891, and then the eastern state of Brandenburg, with 739.
"I thought the map was useful, it shows that this isn't just happening in east Germany, which we are often told is the case," said Puest.
The production and distribution of neo-Nazi material is illegal in Germany, and much of the propaganda comes from abroad, the agency said.

Much extreme right-wing propaganda is published in Lincoln, Nebraska in the United States, where a group called the NSDAP-AO -- or "Nazi foreign development agency" -- produces racist and inflammatory material for German neo-Nazi groups.
Other exhibits include a selection of songs by skinhead bands like Glatzenparty (Skinhead party), Close Shave and Volkszorn (People's Rage).

The songs contain racist lyrics along the lines of "We really hate bloody foreigners", or violent neo-Nazi sentiments such as: "We are skinheads, the brownshirts of today, we are skinheads, always ready to fight."
The number of violent attacks by right-wing extremists has been on the downturn in recent years, from a peak of 2,639 attacks in 1992 to 837 in 1995.
